discussion.content:
From the provided link, "Using up to 8 ASA appliances, clustering can allow up to 100Gbps of aggregate traffic. The ASA cluster does not actively load balance flows."

But from "Designing for Cisco Network Service Architectures (ARCH) Foundation Learning Guide, Fourth Edition" book,

"Cisco ASA clustering, introduced in the 9.0 release, enables you to bundle multiple ASA devices into a single cluster. The data traffic is load-balanced between cluster members."

Not sure...

questions.question_text: Which two features are from a scalable cluster design utilizing Cisco ASA firewalls? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The design supports up to 1 Terabyte of aggregate traffic.
choices.E: The design supports up to 100 Gbps of aggregate traffic.
choices.B: Each member of the cluster can forward every traffic flow.
choices.C: The ASA cluster actively load balances traffic flows.
choices.A: Each cluster supports up to 10 ASA devices.

questions.question_text: Which two of these are correct regarding the recommended practice for distribution layer design? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
answer is A&E 
summarization between distribution and core not between distributions

choices.E: use a Layer 3 link between distribution switches without route summarization
choices.B: use a Layer 2 link between distribution switches
choices.A: use a redundant link to the core
choices.C: never use a redundant link to the core because of convergence issues
choices.D: use a Layer 3 link between distribution switches with route summarization

choices.A: only the low-order 23 bits of the MAC address are used to map IP addresses
choices.D: only the low-order 23 bits of the IP address are used to map MAC addresses
choices.E: the 0x01004f MAC address prefix is used for mapping IP addresses to MAC addresses
choices.C: only the high-order 23 bits of the MAC address are used to map IP addresses
choices.B: only the low-order 24 bits of the MAC address are used to map IP addresses
choices.F: the 0x01005e MAC address prefix is used for mapping IP addresses to MAC addresses

discussion.content: The answer MUST be D and F. "The sending device must convert the destination IP multicast address into a special MAC address..." doing the following: "the lower-order 23 bits of the destination IP multicast address are mapped to the lower-order 23 bits of the MAC address."

comments.content: agree, D and F are correct

questions.question_text: Which two design concerns must be addressed when designing a multicast implementation? (Choose two.)

choices.D: The traffic must be remarked to a lower priority to and allowed to pass.
choices.C: The traffic within the real-time queue must not be limited.
choices.A: The traffic must be policed and not allowed to pass.
choices.B: The traffic must be shaped to allow for it to be transmitted after the tokens have been replenished.

discussion.content: I think A is the answer

questions.question_text: While designing a QoS policy for an organization, a network engineer is determining the method to limit the output rate of traffic within the real-time queue. How must the limiting of traffic within the real-time queue occur?

discussion.content: Think it should be Root Guard instead.

questions.question_text: Which STP feature can prevent other switches on the network from becoming the root switch, but still allow that interface to particiate in STP otherwise?
